title: ICML_2006_119_abs

sentences.text: We investigate the problem of learning to predict moves in the board game of Go from game records of expert players .
In particular , we obtain a probability distribution over legal moves for professional play in a given position .
This distribution has numerous applications in computer Go , including serving as an efficient stand-alone Go player .
It would also be effective as a move selector and move sorter for game tree search and as a training tool for Go players .

Our method has two major components : a -RRB- a pattern extraction scheme for efficiently harvesting patterns of given size and shape from expert game records and b -RRB- a Bayesian learning algorithm -LRB- in two variants -RRB- that learns a distribution over the values of a move given a board position based on the local pattern context .

The system is trained on 181,000 expert games and shows excellent prediction performance as indicated by its ability to perfectly predict the moves made by professional Go players in 34 % of test positions .

Entity-learning_to_predict_move.label: learning to predict moves
aliases: the problem of learning to predict moves in the board game of Go
Entity-learning_to_predict_move.description: Learning to predict moves refers to a machine learning task aimed at developing a predictive model that estimates the probability distribution of legal moves in the board game of Go based on patterns extracted from expert game records.

mentions.local_name: the problem of learning to predict moves in the board game of Go

Entity-our_method.label: Our method
Entity-our_method.description: Our method refers to a two-component approach for predicting moves in the game of Go, which includes a pattern extraction scheme for harvesting patterns from expert game records and a Bayesian learning algorithm that learns a distribution over move values based on board position and local pattern context.

Entity-system.label: system
Entity-system.description: The system refers to a Bayesian learning algorithm designed to predict moves in the board game of Go, trained on expert game records to generate a probability distribution over legal moves.

Entity-problem.label: problem
Entity-problem.description: The problem refers to the challenge of developing a method to predict moves in the board game of Go by analyzing game records from expert players.

Entity-this_distribution.label: This distribution
Entity-this_distribution.description: This distribution refers to the probability distribution over legal moves in the board game of Go, derived from expert game records, which is utilized for various applications in computer Go, such as move selection and training tools.

Entity-move.label: move
Entity-move.description: In the context of the board game Go, 'move' refers to a legal action taken by a player in response to the current board position, which is predicted using a Bayesian learning algorithm based on patterns extracted from expert game records.

Entity-distribution.label: distribution
Entity-distribution.description: The term 'distribution' refers to a probability distribution over legal moves in the board game of Go, which is derived from expert game records and is used to predict moves based on the current board position.

Entity-pattern_extraction_scheme.label: pattern extraction scheme
Entity-pattern_extraction_scheme.description: The pattern extraction scheme is an algorithm designed to efficiently harvest patterns of specified size and shape from expert game records in the context of predicting moves in the board game of Go.

Entity-training_tool_for_go_player.label: training tool for Go players
Entity-training_tool_for_go_player.description: A training tool for Go players refers to a system or method that utilizes a learned probability distribution over legal moves in the game of Go, derived from expert game records, to assist players in improving their strategic decision-making and move selection during gameplay.

Entity-local_pattern_context.label: local pattern context
Entity-local_pattern_context.description: The 'local pattern context' refers to the specific arrangement and characteristics of patterns derived from expert game records in the board game of Go, which are used to inform a Bayesian learning algorithm about the probability distribution of legal moves based on the current board position.

Entity-distribution_over_the_value_of_a_.label: distribution over the values of a move
aliases: distribution over the values of a move
Entity-distribution_over_the_value_of_a_.description: The 'distribution over the values of a move' refers to a probabilistic model that predicts the likelihood of different moves in the game of Go based on the current board position and local patterns derived from expert game records.

mentions.local_name: distribution over the values of a move

Entity-34_.description: The mention '34 %' refers to the percentage of test positions in the board game of Go where the system is able to perfectly predict the moves made by professional players.

Entity-move_selector.label: move selector
Entity-move_selector.description: The 'move selector' refers to a component of a system designed to predict and select optimal moves in the board game of Go, utilizing a probability distribution derived from expert game records to enhance game tree search and training for players.

Entity-game_record.label: game records
Entity-game_record.description: Game records refer to the documented sequences of moves and strategies used by expert players in the board game of Go, which are utilized for training algorithms to predict future moves.

Entity-expert_game.label: expert games
Entity-expert_game.description: Expert games refer to a dataset consisting of 181,000 game records from professional Go players, used for training a model to predict moves in the game.

Entity-expert_game_record.label: expert game records
Entity-expert_game_record.description: Expert game records refer to the collected game data from professional players of the board game Go, which is used to analyze and predict moves based on established patterns and strategies.

Entity-numerous_application.label: numerous applications
Entity-numerous_application.description: The term 'numerous applications' refers to the various uses of the probability distribution over legal moves in the board game of Go, which includes functioning as an efficient stand-alone Go player, a move selector, a move sorter for game tree search, and a training tool for Go players.

Entity-two_variant.label: two variants
Entity-two_variant.description: The term 'two variants' refers to the two different implementations of a Bayesian learning algorithm used to learn a distribution over the values of a move in the game of Go, based on the local pattern context derived from expert game records.

Entity-expert_player.label: expert players
Entity-expert_player.description: Expert players refer to highly skilled individuals who play the board game Go at a professional level, whose game records are used to train algorithms for predicting moves in the game.

Entity-move_made_by_professional_go_play.label: moves made by professional Go players
aliases: moves made by professional Go players
Entity-move_made_by_professional_go_play.description: The term 'moves made by professional Go players' refers to the specific actions or decisions taken by expert players during a game of Go, which are analyzed and predicted using a system trained on extensive game records to enhance the understanding and performance of both human and computer players.

mentions.local_name: moves made by professional Go players

Entity-move_sorter.label: move sorter
Entity-move_sorter.description: The 'move sorter' refers to a component of a system designed to predict and evaluate moves in the board game of Go, which organizes and prioritizes potential moves based on their predicted effectiveness in a given game position.

Entity-professional_play.label: professional play
Entity-professional_play.description: Professional play refers to the gameplay exhibited by expert Go players, characterized by high-level strategic decision-making and skill, from which a probability distribution over legal moves is derived for predictive modeling.

Entity-a_given_position.label: a given position
Entity-a_given_position.description: In the context of the board game Go, 'a given position' refers to a specific arrangement of stones on the board at a particular moment in the game, which is used to analyze and predict the legal moves available to players.

Entity-position.label: position
Entity-position.description: In the context of the board game Go, 'position' refers to the specific arrangement of pieces on the board at a given moment in the game, which is crucial for predicting legal moves and strategies.

Entity-test_position.label: test positions
Entity-test_position.description: Test positions refer to specific board configurations in the game of Go used to evaluate the performance of a predictive model by measuring its accuracy in predicting moves made by professional players.

Entity-stand-alone_go_player.label: stand-alone Go player
Entity-stand-alone_go_player.description: The term 'stand-alone Go player' refers to a computer system designed to independently play the board game Go by predicting moves based on a learned probability distribution from expert game records.

Entity-probability_distribution_over_leg.label: probability distribution over legal moves for professional play
aliases: probability distribution over legal moves for professional play
Entity-probability_distribution_over_leg.description: A mathematical representation that quantifies the likelihood of each possible legal move in a game setting, specifically tailored for professional-level gameplay.

mentions.local_name: probability distribution over legal moves for professional play

Entity-legal_move.label: legal moves
Entity-legal_move.description: Legal moves refer to the valid actions that a player can take in the board game of Go, which are determined based on the current state of the game and the rules governing play.

Entity-computer_go.label: computer Go
Entity-computer_go.description: Computer Go refers to the use of artificial intelligence and computer algorithms to play the board game Go, often involving the development of programs that can compete against human players.

Entity-go_player.label: Go player
Entity-go_player.description: A Go player is an individual who participates in the board game Go, engaging in strategic gameplay that involves placing black and white stones on a grid to capture territory.

Entity-go.label: Go
Entity-go.description: Go is a strategic board game originating from East Asia, played by two players who take turns placing black and white stones on a grid, with the objective of capturing territory.

Entity-game_tree_search.label: game tree search
Entity-game_tree_search.description: Game tree search is a computational method used to explore possible moves in a game by representing the game's possible states and decisions in a tree structure, allowing for the evaluation of strategies and outcomes.

Entity-bayesian_learning_algorithm.label: Bayesian learning algorithm
Entity-bayesian_learning_algorithm.description: A Bayesian learning algorithm is a statistical method used in machine learning that applies Bayes' theorem to update the probability distribution of a hypothesis as more evidence or information becomes available.

Entity-move_sorter_for_game_tree_search.label: move sorter for game tree search
aliases: move sorter for game tree search
Entity-move_sorter_for_game_tree_search.description: A move sorter for game tree search is a computational tool designed to organize and prioritize potential moves in a game tree, enhancing the efficiency of decision-making processes in strategic games.

mentions.local_name: move sorter for game tree search

Entity-prediction_performance.label: prediction performance
Entity-prediction_performance.description: Prediction performance refers to the effectiveness of a model or system in accurately forecasting outcomes or behaviors based on input data.

Entity-probability_distribution.label: probability distribution
Entity-probability_distribution.description: A probability distribution is a mathematical function that describes the likelihood of different outcomes in a random experiment, assigning probabilities to each possible value or range of values.

Entity-training_tool.label: training tool
Entity-training_tool.description: A training tool is a resource or software designed to enhance skills and knowledge in a specific area, often through practice and interactive learning.

summary: We investigate the problem of learning to predict moves in the board game of Go from game records of expert players . In particular , we obtain a probability distribution over legal moves for professional play in a given position . This distribution has numerous applications in computer Go , including serving as an efficient stand-alone Go player . It would also be effective as a move selector and move sorter for game tree search and as a training tool for Go players . Our method has two major components : a -RRB- a pattern extraction scheme for efficiently harvesting patterns of given size and shape from expert game records and b -RRB- a Bayesian learning algorithm -LRB- in two variants -RRB- that learns a distribution over the values of a move given a board position based on the local pattern context . The system is trained on 181,000 expert games and shows excellent prediction performance as indicated by its ability to perfectly predict the moves made by professional Go players in 34 % of test positions .

Predicate-investigate.label: investigate
Predicate-investigate.description: The predicate 'investigate' denotes the action of examining, exploring, or inquiring into a subject or object in order to gain deeper understanding, uncover information, or analyze its characteristics. In the context of the triple, it signifies that the subject is actively engaging in a process aimed at understanding or analyzing the object, which may involve observation, research, or experimentation.

Predicate-used_for.label: used for
Predicate-used_for.description: The predicate 'used for' indicates a functional relationship where the subject serves a specific purpose or utility in relation to the object. It implies that the subject is employed or utilized in a manner that facilitates, supports, or contributes to the achievement of the objective represented by the object.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: The predicate 'provide' indicates an action where the subject offers, supplies, or makes available something to the object. It establishes a relationship in which the subject is the source or giver of the object, which is the item or information being supplied.

Predicate-investigates.label: investigates
Predicate-investigates.description: The predicate 'investigates' denotes an action where the subject actively examines, explores, or studies the object in order to gain insights, understand its nature, or uncover information related to it. This process often involves inquiry, analysis, and critical thinking, aiming to reveal underlying factors or solutions associated with the object.

Predicate-obtains.label: obtains
Predicate-obtains.description: The predicate 'obtains' indicates a relationship where the subject acquires, receives, or gains possession of the object. It implies a transition from a state of not having the object to a state of having it, often as a result of a process, action, or interaction. In this context, the subject is actively involved in the process of obtaining the object, which can represent information, resources, or capabilities.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or ownership between the subject and the object. It signifies that the subject possesses certain characteristics, qualities, or entities represented by the object. In this context, the subject is the entity that holds or contains the object, which can be an abstract concept, a physical item, or a set of attributes.

Predicate-serves_as.label: serves as
Predicate-serves_as.description: The predicate 'serves as' indicates a functional or role-based relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject fulfills the role or function described by the object in a specific context.

Predicate-is_effective_as.label: is effective as
Predicate-is_effective_as.description: The predicate 'is effective as' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object, indicating that the subject performs its function or role in a manner that achieves desired outcomes or results comparable to the object. It suggests that the subject possesses qualities or capabilities that make it suitable or advantageous for the purpose represented by the object.

Predicate-is_effective_for.label: is effective for
Predicate-is_effective_for.description: The predicate 'is effective for' establishes a relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject serves a beneficial purpose or achieves a desired outcome specifically for the object. It implies that the subject has a positive impact or utility in relation to the object, suggesting that the object can gain advantages or improvements through the use of the subject.

Predicate-learns.label: learns
Predicate-learns.description: The predicate 'learns' indicates a process in which the subject acquires knowledge, skills, or understanding related to the object. It signifies an active engagement where the subject processes information or experiences to develop a deeper comprehension or capability concerning the object, which represents the content or context being learned.

Predicate-is_given_by.label: is given by
Predicate-is_given_by.description: The predicate 'is given by' establishes a relationship where the subject is defined or determined by the object. It indicates that the subject's existence, state, or action is contingent upon or derived from the object, suggesting a dependency or attribution of characteristics from the object to the subject.

Predicate-is_trained_on.label: is trained on
Predicate-is_trained_on.description: The predicate 'is trained on' indicates a relationship where the subject has undergone a process of learning or development using the object as a source of knowledge, data, or experience. It implies that the subject has been exposed to the object in a manner that enhances its capabilities or understanding, often in a specific domain or context.

Predicate-predicts.label: predicts
Predicate-predicts.description: The predicate 'predicts' establishes a relationship where the subject, typically an entity or system, provides an estimation or forecast regarding a future event or outcome, represented by the object, which often quantifies the likelihood or expected value of that event.

Predicate-addresses.label: addresses
Predicate-addresses.description: The predicate 'addresses' indicates that the subject is focused on or concerned with the object, often implying that the subject provides a solution, response, or consideration to the issues or topics represented by the object.

Predicate-is_implemented_by.label: is implemented by
Predicate-is_implemented_by.description: The predicate 'is implemented by' establishes a relationship where the subject, typically a system or framework, is realized or executed through the methods, processes, or techniques described by the object. It indicates that the functionality or behavior of the subject is achieved by utilizing the strategies or actions specified in the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or category that falls under the more general category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a wider range of entities or concepts, of which the subject is a part.
